turn.3: I found the quote I was thinking of... an anecdote from Richard Feynman, arguably one of the greatest physicists of the 20th century.   &#x200B;  >When I was a  kid growing up in Far Rockaway, I  had a friend named Bernie Walker. turn.5: The whole piece is worth reading - it talks about how some people count to themselves audibly (imagining a voice counting, as it were), and some people count to themselves visually (imagining watching a clock) - and how the different types of thinking to yourself affects your ability to do different things simultaneously.      Goes on to describe how Feynman then tried to learn to do both (as have I since reading this. And like Feynman, have failed).      More importantly, the larger point of the story is about how even basic everyday things that are "universal" can be done in completely unexpected and, frankly, alien seeming ways for other people! :)
